import React, { useState, useEffect, useRef } from 'react'; import "../css/styles.css"; import { Routes, Route, Link } from "react-router-dom"; import Posts from "./Posts"; import Library from "./Library"; import IndexPage from "./IndexPage"; function Energy() { // State for theme toggle const [theme, setTheme] = useState("dark"); // Assuming 'dark' is default from your HTML // State for TOC visibility const [isTocOpen, setIsTocOpen] = useState(false); // Ref for citation copy button to manage icons const citationCopyButtonRef = useRef(null); // Function to toggle theme const toggleTheme = () => { setTheme((currentTheme) => (currentTheme === "dark" ? "light" : "dark")); }; // Function to toggle TOC visibility const toggleTOC = () => { setIsTocOpen(!isTocOpen); }; // Function to copy citation const copyCitation = (event) => { const citationText = `@misc{bradley-energy-2024, title={Matter & Motion: The Energy Revolution}, author={Bradley, Ben}, year={2024}, month={jan}, note={Blog post}, howpublished={\\url{bbradz.github.com}} }`; navigator.clipboard .writeText(citationText) .then(() => { if (citationCopyButtonRef.current) { citationCopyButtonRef.current.innerHTML = ` `; setTimeout(() => { if (citationCopyButtonRef.current) { citationCopyButtonRef.current.innerHTML = ` `; } }, 2000); } }) .catch((err) => { console.error("Could not copy citation: ", err); alert("Failed to copy citation to clipboard."); }); }; // Function to scroll to top const scrollToTop = () => { window.scrollTo({ top: 0, behavior: "smooth", }); }; // Function to handle history back const goBack = () => { window.history.back(); }; // Effect to set data-theme on body useEffect(() => { document.body.setAttribute("data-theme", theme); }, [theme]); // Effect to load external scripts (Polyfill and MathJax) useEffect(() => { const polyfillScript = document.createElement("script"); polyfillScript.src = "https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"; document.head.appendChild(polyfillScript); const mathJaxScript = document.createElement("script"); mathJaxScript.id = "MathJax-script"; mathJaxScript.async = true; mathJaxScript.src = "https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"; document.head.appendChild(mathJaxScript); return () => { document.head.removeChild(polyfillScript); document.head.removeChild(mathJaxScript); }; }, []); return ( bb.radz aatter & motion

BBradz

Posts {" "} {/* Consider using if using React Router for these paths */} Library {" "} {/* Consider using if using React Router for these paths */} About Me {" "} {/* Consider using if using React Router for these paths */}

Matter & Motion

Ben Bradley, Feb 21st, 2024 ‚Ä¢ 9 min read (1.7K words)
Energy Green Tech Sustainability
‚ñ∂ Table of Contents
  1. The Benefits of Scale üìà
  2. Bright times ahead ‚òÄÔ∏è
  3. Wright‚Äôs Law in other parts of the Energy Revolution
  4. Nuclear üß©
  5. In Conclusion
  6. Sources

Look around you, actually look.

One simple question: how much work do you think it took to make everything within arms reach of you?

From city-sized semiconductor fabs to GPT gpu clusters with more compute power than global powers its impossible to imagine the scope of energy needed to build and run the factories, machines, transportation, information distribution system, and (lest we forget‚Äî) workers that bring you the products you use and enjoy every day. The modern industrial complex sprawls across oceans and continents taking every form economically justifiable but, at the end of the day, with enough abstraction it can be boiled down into 2 distinct ingredients: material to be molded and energy to do the molding.

Everything anyone on Earth will materially every touch, want, and need is produced by a chain of people using two things: resources and energy.

~Matter and Motion~

Maybe you like to turn to empirical observations on life satisfaction and the globally nearly presupposed capitalist growth imperative if that appeals to you. Or turn to the 4+ billion people around the world living on $6.85 or less in income every day for whom global material abundance means the most. Regardless, if you personally want to live in a world with more of the material things you use as well and improved things you didn‚Äôt even think you needed then you should care a lot about how good the very smart people who are making the things you use are at taking advantage of Matter and Motion to make the things you and all of us use.

That‚Äôs where this article comes in. The recipe for material well-being has two necessary inputs and I'd like to do a little deep dive into how the second part of that equation ‚ÄîMotion‚Äî is undergoing a global revolution with every passing day. Plummeting costs lead to surging capacities lead to the ability to utilize exponential degrees of energy for molding the clay of the universe into whatever forms we as humans and want to survive and thrive.

The Benefits of Scale üìà

The key to understanding the energy abundance we‚Äôll be seeing more and more is a little thing known as Wright‚Äôs Law which states the more times a task has been performed the less time each subsequent unit begins to take. Essentially, if you make a crazy number of units you get crazily fast and efficient at making even more.

Wright‚Äôs Law is a verifiable component of unit-cost trends in all sorts of industries having been discovered at NASA when they observed consistent 15% reductions in costs per unit in Aerospace components for every doubling of total units produced and comes down to a confluence factors. These include increased:

  1. Labor Efficiency & Specialization
  2. Standardization
  3. Development of Technologies
  4. Engineering Reworks
  5. Network Effects
  6. and Shared Experience

Wright‚Äôs Law can be seen in the price of production for Model Ts as well‚Ä¶

From 1909 to 1923, for every doubling in the cumulative Model Ts produced the prices of the newest car had fallen by 15%

Today we‚Äôre seeing the effects of Moore‚Äôs Law everywhere, we‚Äôve been seeing a doubling in transistor densities and halving of compute costs every 2 years for 60 years now.

These dynamics are everywhere with most products falling between the 20 and 10 percent range in price for every doubling in scale and Wind & Solar energy are no different. Rapid scaling in productive capacity is beginning to plot a Wright‚Äôs Law of Green Energy tracking how the scaling of Wind & Solar is reducing the cost of renewables to astonishing degrees.

Bright times ahead ‚òÄÔ∏è

Empirical observation from the past decade and a half of Solar prices show that for every doubling in the cumulative amount of global solar installations we‚Äôve seen a 30-40 (!) % decrease in prices ( 15% in the case of wind)

How much more room is there for Solar and Wind to scale and what does Wright‚Äôs Law therefore tell us about the future of energy as Wind & Solar come to rule grid production?

The numbers work out so that we have enough room to double the cumulative quantity of solar 5 times over in the process of transitioning the global energy production over to renewables, a project which we‚Äôre already needing to do to prevent Climate destruction. Utilizing that observed 30-40% learning rate energy costs from new solar should begin to approach a single cent per kWh by 2040, nearly 1/20 of the current going rate.

Solar costs already outcompete nearly 99% of coal plants but with this continued scaling up we‚Äôll begin to be see sustainable energy as the only economically relevant choice simultaneously causing the cost of energy to be driven down for everyone.

Dealing with a water crisis? Energy is 1/2 of the price of desalination plants .

Need to Air Condition a continent? Very energy intensive.

It‚Äôs all Matter & Motion and with the cost of Motion diving so does the cost of everything else it‚Äôs used to make.

Wright‚Äôs Law in other parts of the Energy Revolution

Looking at peak energy draw by hour in a state like California, energy consumption peaks as people are getting home from work and turn on their Kitchens and TVs to kick back for the night. Because of that, the cost of energy in the future relies not only on the abundance of solar capacity but also on the cost of storing that energy from the peak hours until when it becomes needed.

The price of Lithium-Ion batteries dropped by a factor of 40 between 1992 and 2016 with a 5.5 fold increase in cumulative installed capacity, working out to a 15% learning rate or 21% when looking at post-EV years only.

All of the large lithium-ion batteries in 2015 combined stored the equivalent of less than a minute of global electricity demand leaving tons of room for continued scaling. Starting with the 2015 price of batteries, around 25 cents per kWh, by the time the planet has sufficient lithium-ion storage to hold 13 minutes of it‚Äôs yearly electricity demand lithium-ion prices will have dropped by a factor of 2 to 2.5 or 10-13 cents per kWh.

At the point of being able to store an hour of electricity demand (which projections estimate will happen sometime around 2030 ) prices will be in the range of 6-9 cents and when storage reaches a full day of demand it will be 2-4 cents per kWh.

That‚Äôs the maximum cost which energy should ever approach under a solar only world, and it‚Äôs incredibly cheap. Other projects which would help to reduce that energy production versus energy usage time offset include:

  1. Investing in a proper national grid to better allocate electricity supply across regions.

  2. and Nuclear! More on that in a second‚Ä¶

Bringing down the cost of batteries and developing making them increasingly efficient is key in unlocking the electrification of parts of the global economy currently locked into emitting CO2 by the limitations of the batteries we‚Äôre stuck with today. Transportation makes up nearly 1/5 of global CO2 emissions and while we‚Äôve already began electrifying cars and are making real progress on trucking, shipping and aviation both need the resources and attention of a tremendously scaled battery industry in order to have the resources to make battery innovations which make electric boats and planes possible.

We just need to keep the growth curves going.

Nuclear üß©

I mentioned earlier how one of the primary issues with the nature of solar (and wind) energy is that it ebbs and flows based on weather, time of the day, and time of year. Well, while I‚Äôm generally all-in on government subsidies being funneled into Solar, Wind, and Battery technology the biggest potential sources for cheap energy abundance, there‚Äôs a good conversation to be had about the indispensability of nuclear as a baseline energy provider where renewables fail.

The major issues with Solar and Wind are that:

  1. They‚Äôre less efficient in some parts of the world
  2. They have a variable daily, even hourly, output
  3. They take up huge amounts of land

Nuclear takes up very little land and runs very consistently which makes it a perfect low environmental impact option for:

  • Places where solar and wind isn‚Äôt possible at scale like: densely inhabited areas, small islands, or polar climates and‚Ä¶
  • As baseline supply for when renewable sources dries up from seasonal or weather fluctuations

Modern nuclear reactors generally take up anywhere from 75 to 150 times less space than similar energy output solar farms (*including the space needed for batteries) so nuclear can be really good option depending on land availability or environmental issues with developing large swaths of land.

While I don‚Äôt expect Nuclear to get as cheap as Solar can be because of the tight regulations on building reactors which force costs higher to pay off building costs, some regulations should almost definitely be loosened on the{" "} whether people who want to build nuclear reactors are allowed to build them {" "} front (as opposed to the{" "} how tightly monitored those who are building nuclear reactors are {" "} front, which is probably good right now).

But isn‚Äôt Nuclear power unsafe? No. Modern nuclear reactors literally cannot melt down in the ways that Chernobyl or Fukushima fell apart.

Nuclear Fusion has also been plodding forward relentlessly for decades and any decade now it will become economically feasible, at that point Fusion will also become a great source for baseline energy supply.

In Conclusion:

Phase 1: Invest in scaling Solar + Nuclear for baseline power

Phase 2: Electrify transportation + unlock Fusion

References

1. batteries can get pretty damn cheap üìï . Ramez Naam, 2015.
2. solar is going to be VERY cheap üìï . Ramez Naam, 2020.
3. answering the techno-optimists - noahpinion üìï . Noahpinion.
4. techno-optimism 2023 (batteries / fusion) üìï . Noahpinion, 2023.
5. Nuclear Power Is Good Actually üé• . YouTube.
6. Solar is happening. Nuclear is (mostly) not. üìï . Noahpinion.
7. Nuclear Power Take Up Less Space Than Solar or Wind üìï . Bloomberg, 2023.
